TextEquiv.Unicode: goeth before his Disciples into Gali
le : presently after hee commeth into
Jurie againe, where his body was ta
ken up from mount Olivet into heave.
All this doth proove the certaine veri
tie of Christ his bodie. But because
this bodie (although it be a true and
very body of the owne proper kind,
place, disposition, and of the owne pro
per shape, and nature) is called a glo
rified and glorious bodie, I will saie
somewhat of that glory, which verily
is incident to the true shape and sub
stance of the body once raised uppe a
gaine.
First glory in this sense is used for
a lightsomnesse and shining bright
nesse. For Paul saith, that the children
of Israel for the glory of Moses coun
tenance, coulde not beholde with their
eies the face of Moses : so then a glo
rious body is a bright and shining bo
dy. A very good proofe of this did our
Lord shew, even a little before his re
surrection, whe it pleased him to give
to his Disciples a small taste of the
glory to come, and for that cause took a
side certaine whom he had chosen into
the top of a certaine hil, where he was
transsigured before them, so that the
fashion of his countenance did shine as
the sunne, and his clothes were white
& glistered as the light. The Lord veri
ly had stil the same bodily substance, &
the same members of the body, but
they we re transeigured.
But it is manifest, that that transfi
guratio was in ye accidents: For light
and brightnesse was added, so that the
shape & substance of the countenaunce
and bodie remayning as it was, the
countenaunce and body did glister as
the Sunne & the light. And although
wee reade not, that the bodye of the
Lord did within those 40. daies, wher
in h

goeth before his Disciples into Gali le : presently after hee commeth into Jurie againe, where his body was ta ken up from mount Olivet into heave. All this doth proove the certaine veri tie of Christ his bodie. But because this bodie (although it be a true and very body of the owne proper kind, place, disposition, and of the owne pro per shape, and nature) is called a glo rified and glorious bodie, I will saie somewhat of that glory, which verily is incident to the true shape and sub stance of the body once raised uppe a gaine. First glory in this sense is used for a lightsomnesse and shining bright nesse. For Paul saith, that the children of Israel for the glory of Moses coun tenance, coulde not beholde with their eies the face of Moses : so then a glo rious body is a bright and shining bo dy. A very good proofe of this did our Lord shew, even a little before his re surrection, whe it pleased him to give to his Disciples a small taste of the glory to come, and for that cause took a side certaine whom he had chosen into the top of a certaine hil, where he was transsigured before them, so that the fashion of his countenance did shine as the sunne, and his clothes were white & glistered as the light. The Lord veri ly had stil the same bodily substance, & the same members of the body, but they we re transeigured. But it is manifest, that that transfi guratio was in ye accidents: For light and brightnesse was added, so that the shape & substance of the countenaunce and bodie remayning as it was, the countenaunce and body did glister as the Sunne & the light. And although wee reade not, that the bodye of the Lord did within those 40. daies, wher in h
his Disciples, make manifest & spread
abroade the brightnesse which it had,
and that by reason of the dispensation,
whereby also he did eate with his dis
ciples, notwithstanding that clarified
bodies neede not foode or nourishment
at all : yet neverthelesse his bodie shi
neth nowe in Heaven, as John in the
first of the Apocalipse witnesseth, and
the sacred Scriptures laye an allured
hope before us, that even our bodies
also shall in the resurrection bee like
wise clarified. For the Lorde himelfe
in the Gospell alleadging the wordes
of Daniel, saith: Then shall the righ
teous shine as the Sonne in his fathers
kingdome. For this cause the glori
ous bodies are called also clarified of
the clearnesse of that heavenly bright
nesse, wherewith they glister and are
adorned.
Secondarily, glorie and vilenesse
are made contraries. For Paul saith,
Hee shall chaunge our vile bodie, to
make it in fashion like ro his glorious
bodie. In these wordes, Vilenesse and
Glorie, are set the one agaynst the o
ther. Vilenesse comprehendeth the
whole packe of miseries and infirmi
ties, passions and affections, which
for sinne was layde uppon the bodie,
From all which our bodies are pur
ged in the resurrection of life: so that
then the glorious bodies are bodies
dreined from the dregges of all cor
ruption, passions and infirmities, and
clad with eternitie, heavenlie feeling
and glorie. For the Apostle saith: It is
sowen in corruption, itriseth in in
corruption: it is sowen in dishonour,
it riseth in glorie: it is sowen in infir
mitie, it riseth in poler : it is sowen a
naturall bodie, it tiseth a spiritual bo
die. The giftes therefore of the glo
rious & clarified bodies are very great
and manye, as incorruption, glorie,

his Disciples, make manifest & spread abroade the brightnesse which it had, and that by reason of the dispensation, whereby also he did eate with his dis ciples, notwithstanding that clarified bodies neede not foode or nourishment at all : yet neverthelesse his bodie shi neth nowe in Heaven, as John in the first of the Apocalipse witnesseth, and the sacred Scriptures laye an allured hope before us, that even our bodies also shall in the resurrection bee like wise clarified. For the Lorde himelfe in the Gospell alleadging the wordes of Daniel, saith: Then shall the righ teous shine as the Sonne in his fathers kingdome. For this cause the glori ous bodies are called also clarified of the clearnesse of that heavenly bright nesse, wherewith they glister and are adorned. Secondarily, glorie and vilenesse are made contraries. For Paul saith, Hee shall chaunge our vile bodie, to make it in fashion like ro his glorious bodie. In these wordes, Vilenesse and Glorie, are set the one agaynst the o ther. Vilenesse comprehendeth the whole packe of miseries and infirmi ties, passions and affections, which for sinne was layde uppon the bodie, From all which our bodies are pur ged in the resurrection of life: so that then the glorious bodies are bodies dreined from the dregges of all cor ruption, passions and infirmities, and clad with eternitie, heavenlie feeling and glorie. For the Apostle saith: It is sowen in corruption, itriseth in in corruption: it is sowen in dishonour, it riseth in glorie: it is sowen in infir mitie, it riseth in poler : it is sowen a naturall bodie, it tiseth a spiritual bo die.
